Book_of_Enoch.description: Popular apocalyptic literature among second-Temple Jews; cited by the Dead Sea Scrolls community.
Book_of_Enoch.why_it_might_have_been_present: Fragments of 1 Enoch (e.g., 4Q203) were found at Qumran, suggesting that such works circulated among the priesthood.
Book_of_Enoch.evidence: Fragments of 1 Enoch (e.g., 4Q203) were found at Qumran

Jubilees.description: 2 Maccabean-style rewriting of Genesis. Emphasizes priestly authority and ritual purity; used by the Essenes as a liturgical guide.
Jubilees.why_it_might_have_been_present: A Jubilees scroll (4Q364) was discovered at Qumran, indicating that Temple officials may have possessed copies.

Apocryphal_Psalms_Odes.description: Supplementary hymnody used in Temple worship.
Apocryphal_Psalms_Odes.why_it_might_have_been_present: 1Q161 (Psalm 151) is a unique scroll that likely originated in a Jerusalem liturgical context.

Legal_Tractates.description: Hypothetical priestly law codes that regulated Temple conduct.
Legal_Tractates.why_it_might_have_been_present: The Mishnah (Middot 2:3) mentions a 'scroll of the law of the Temple' that was stored in the Holy of Holies; no physical copy survives, but the textual tradition points to its existence.
